journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part I: Journal of Systems and Control Engineering

title-group.article-title: Analysis of loading effect of systems in a bond graph approach with application to a synchronous machine

contrib-group.aff: Faculty of Electrical Engineering, University of Michoacan, Santiago Tapia No. 403, Col. Centro, Morelia 58000, Mexico. email: gilmichga@yahoo.com.mx

abstract.p: A new type of bond designed as an adapted bond is proposed. This bond can be considered in the transition from an active bond to a bond. This approach makes it possible to know the loading effect of the controller–plant and the feedback connections. In order to determine the loading effect of the closed-loop system, the transfer function using causal paths and causal loops of the system in the physical domain is presented. However, this proposed adapted bond should be used in fault cases. Finally, some examples of bond graph models in open- and closed-loop systems are given.

sec.title: 1 Introduction
sec.p: Load flow can have an adverse effect on system performance, but in the majority of applications settings are calculated where load flow is either assumed to be zero or considered in a cursory manner. However, there are certain schemes for which load flow must be comprehensively analysed to permit a viable application.
In other cases load flow is neglected and the system will perform properly until a contingency situation arises that causes an incorrect system operation attributable to load effects.

The bond graph methodology is an energy-based modelling approach, unifying symbology for phenomena from different physical domains. The essential feature of the bond graph approach is the representation of energetic interactions between systems and/or system components by a single line. Also, the use of a bond graph provides a structured approach to system dynamics modelling [1].

The bond graph models demand conservation of energy. The junction structures, including simple bonds, junctions, transformers, and gyrators, are strictly conservative. Occasionally, one wishes to model a coupler, and this can be done by using an active bond, which is like a simple bond except that the effort or the flow at one end is defined as zero [2].

When automatic control systems are added to physical systems, the control systems usually receive signals by means of nearly ideal instruments and affect the systems through nearly ideal amplifiers. The use of active bonds for such cases simplifies the analysis of the systems. Notice that in using bond graphs, one always assumes that multiports are coupled with both forward and backward effects unless a specific modelling decision has been made that a back effect is negligible [1].

In this paper a new type of bond is proposed. This bond is designed as an adapted bond. An adapted bond is a special bond that, if it begins on the 1-junction, has variables of effort and flow and the effort is multiplied by a parameter. The opposite case is when the adapted bond is connected to the 0-junction, and the variables of flow are multiplied by a parameter and the corresponding effort. The parameter is defined in the interval [0, 1] which makes it possible to consider the loading effect. By neglecting the loading effect the parameter of the adapted bond is zero, having an active bond. The adapted bond will be the traditional bond when the parameter is one. Also, the adapted bond accepts the causal stroke.

The main characteristic of the adapted bond is that the loading effect of a system can be analysed. Moreover, this approach makes it possible to obtain the transfer function directly using the causal paths and causal loops in a closed-loop system.

Li and Ngwompo [3] introduced two new bond graph elements, power scaling transformers (PTFs) and power scaling gyrators (PGYs). These elements satisfy a scaled power continuity and a power scaling bond graph provides a framework to analyse the passivity of mechatronic systems with embedded energy sources and power scaling properties. The PTF and/or PGY can be used as substitute for the proposed adapted bonds in this paper.
In references [4–6] some closed-loop systems are obtained by bond graph models. However, an active bond has to be used in these cases, with the causality problem.

There are several approaches to analyse the load effect in different systems. In reference [7] the load effect of a typical hydraulic power assisted steering (HPAS) system which is widely used in heavy-duty vehicles is shown – it is necessary to compensate the additional load torque during the steering operations to improve the performance of the engine speed regulation by using mathematical models and simulation.

In reference [8] it is shown that the piezoelectric actuator (PEA) accuracy is limited due to hysteresis non-linearity as well as mechanical loading effect. In reference [8] a controller scheme to compensate the mentioned limiting factors in PEA is proposed. The minimum loading resistance of an isolated self-excited reluctance generator (SERG) using a novel approach based on eigen techniques (eigenvalue and eigenvalue sensitivity) is determined in reference [9]. This paper uses the d–q-axis equivalent circuit model of the SERG to obtain the dynamic performance and steady-state characteristics under minimum loading effects.

Also, reference [10] presents a method for removing the load effects from the monitored quantity of induction machines. Simulation shows the effectiveness of the method. An extended transfer function block diagram model, which includes one of the q-axis damper circuits as well as local load, is proposed in reference [11]. A more realistic investigation of the local load effect on the generator damping is given in reference [11].

The previous papers show that the bond graph model with the proposed adapted bond can be applied to describe and to understand the loading effect in physical systems, and that the bond graph is a suitable tool to support engineers in many stages of system design and analysis, involving modelling, simulation, choice of instrumentation/actuator architecture, controller synthesis, and supervision [1, 12–14].

However, it is necessary to explain some important papers that detail model changes of the interconnection structure and storage. In the description of physical system in references [15] and [16], most of the transformations of variables turn out to be power conserving. One is also made aware that system analysis methods based on signal flow or bond graphs using active bonds must be carefully disciplined if formulations valid in a power and energy sense are to result. In reference [17] the switched power junction or SPJ-formalism is revisited and it is shown that a SPJ can be represented by a suitable combination of standard BJ-junctions and Boolean modulated transformers (bMTF).

In reference [18] a technique is proposed that combines bond graph energy flow modelling and signal-flow modelling schemes for modelling discontinuities in physical systems. This enables the generation of complex, multi-mode behaviours without violating the energy flow principles imposed by bond graphs. Mode switching is achieved by controlled junctions which assume that one of the states is on and off. Reference [19] concentrates on the continuous time part of a hybrid system as represented by a bond graph, and the interface between this part of the system and the discrete event part. Also, Gawthrop introduces ISW and CSW components; these are switched I and C that are modulated by binary signals.

In this paper the proposed adapted bond makes it possible to consider the transition between active bond and power bond. However, the main characteristic of an adapted bond is to change the effort or the flow, depending on the junction which is connected, by a parameter. This parameter is the load effect. Nevertheless, it is important to consider that the load effect is not a normal operation condition, but the adapted bond’s usefulness is to recognize possible faults in the system.
References [17] to [19] propose methodologies to model changes in the interconnection structure. However, for this an adapted bond is not used.

In order to use the bond graph elements already available to consider the load effect without adapted bonds, it is possible to change the parameter values of the external bonds for an open-loop system, but for closed-loop systems this would be difficult. This case is not analysed. Also, if a dynamic load effect is considered, that is, if the load is a time function, it is easy to solve this case using an adapted bond. The examples of this paper with dynamic load effect are analysed.

Controller performance is highly dependent on the measurement sensors. Measured process data are inherently inaccurate. These measurement errors can be caused by random noise, or malfunctioning or miscalibrated instruments. Hence, this paper contributes using adapted bonds to analyse the load effect of the feedback or the connection between controller and plant in a closed-loop system [20].

The paper is organized as follows. Section 2, gives some basic elements of the modelling in a bond graph. In section 3 an adapted bond to analyse the loading effect is presented. In order to consider the loading effect of system modelling in bond graphs, section 4 describes an example using adapted bonds. Section 5 presents the loading effect analysis of closed-loop systems in the physical domain. Finally, in section 6 the conclusions are given.

sec.title: 2 Modelling In Bond Graph
sec.p: When two components are connected, power interactions are always present. In the bond graph language, the power variables will be effort e(t) and flow f(t). The power P(t), flowing into or out of a port can be expressed as the product of an effort and a flow variable [1].

The standard elements of bond graphs are classified according to the number of bond as one-ports or multiports. The one-port elements will contain elements which dissipative power, storage energy, and supply power [12].

At each port, both an effort and a flow variable exist, and if one of the effort or flow variables is an input, the other will be the output – the relationship is called causality. Effort and flow are in the opposite directions – the causal stroke is represented by a short, perpendicular line made at one end of a bond and the causal stroke indicates the direction in which the effort signal is directed. Moreover, the directions of power flow and the causal stroke are independent [21].

In certain cases, only one signal exchange between two subsystems can take place, that is, one of the two variables (of effort and flow) can be so minor in relation to the other. Such a bond remains with only one signal and it is called an active bond [1], and is represented by full arrow.
The symbolic form of a bond graph in integral causality assignment of a linear time-invariant (LTI) system is shown in Fig. 1 [12, 21].

caption.p: Key vectors of a bond graph

In the next section a new type of bond is proposed in order to consider the loading effect.

sec.title: 3 An Adapted Bond
sec.p: When a system is dominated by signal interactions due to the presence of instruments, isolating amplifiers, and the like, then either an effort or a flow signal may be suppressed at many interconnection points. In such a case, a bond degenerates to a single signal and may be shown as an active bond [1].

In order to analyse the behaviour of a system with loading effects, a new bond, the adapted bond, on the bond graph model is proposed. The symbol of an adapted bond is formed by two components – the continuous line is the part of a typical bond and the discontinuous line is the approximation part of the bond, as shown in Fig. 2.

caption.p: Adapted bond connecting two subsystems

sec.p: Subsystem B has a loading effect over subsystem A, and thus there are the two cases shown in Fig. 3. The interval of the variable of the adapted bond ξ2 is defined in [0, 1] or 0≤ξ2≤1. For this type of bond, it is possible to have two limit cases.

list-item.p: If ξ2 = 0 then the adapted bond will be an active bond.
If ξ2 = 1 then the adapted bond will be a bond.

caption.p: Adapted bond connecting to junctions

sec.p: In order to explain the usefulness of the adapted bond on systems with loading effect, a system modelled by bond graphs is shown in Fig. 4 where a bond graph represents a subsystem of the source and two bond graphs are loads connected by adapted bonds.

caption.p: System with bond graphs of the source and loads

sec.p: A condition without load with ξ1 = ξ2 = 0 can be analysed. However, loads are connected by active bonds, as shown in Fig. 5. Thus, the bond graph of the source can be seen without loads, but, at the same time, the bond graphs of load 1 and load 2 have maximum effort and flow, respectively. Hence, this represents an ideal operation condition of the source and loads.

caption.p: System with ξ1 = ξ2 = 0

sec.p: When the complete system including source and loads has the maximum load then this operation condition with ξ1 = ξ2 = 1 can be analysed. Thus, the bond graph of the source is connected to the bond graphs of loads by typical bonds, as shown in Fig. 6.

caption.p: System with ξ1 = ξ2 = 1

sec.p: The main contribution of adapted bonds is to analyse load effect of a system. However, the limit cases can be considered.
Considering the connection of an adapted bond in the part of continuous line with typical bonds result in simple relations, as is shown in Fig. 7.

caption.p: Acausal bond graph with two bonds

sec.p: According to Fig. 7(a), f2 = f1 and e2 = e1 and Fig. 7(b) yields f2 = f1 and e2 = e1. Now, if the adapted bond is connected with other bonds which is shown in Fig. 8.

caption.p: Acausal bond graph with two junctions and each junction with three bonds

sec.p: For the 1-junction of Fig. 8, it is possible to have a loading effect
and for the 0-junction

The systematic way of assigning causality to a bond graph model [1] does not change for adapted bonds. By applying the causality to the bond graph model of Fig. 8, it is possible to obtain the causal bond graph shown in Fig. 9.

caption.p: Causal bond graph

sec.p: The relations of the 1-junction are
and of the 0-junction are
Note that, at the outset of the adapted bond being connected to some junction, we have to consider the approximation parameter ξ.

Hence, the adapted bond in a bond graph model as an internal bond is considered. In this context the term internal bond means a bond which is connected to another multiport within the junction structure.

In certain cases, care must be taken with the adapted bond parameter, ξ, because depending of the causality and the connection of the adapted bond, it is possible to have 1/ξ on the mathematical model and the limit case ξ = 0 cannot be applied. When a bond graph model using adapted bonds with a derivative causality assignment (BGD) to obtain the steady state of the system [6], the parameter of some adapted bonds 1/ξ in the bond graph can be applied.

sec.p: It is important to explain the implications of considering adapted bonds in a junction structure. Figure 10 shows a junction structure formed by two junction substructures which are connected by adapted bonds.

sec.title: 5 Load Effect of an Open-Loop System
sec.p: Complicated systems are represented by the interconnection of many subsystems. This section describes an example to apply the loading effect in a bond graph approach using the proposed adapted bonds.

Synchronous generators form the principal source of electric energy in power systems. Many large loads are driven by synchronous motors, and synchronous condensers are sometimes used as a means of providing reactive power compensation and controlling voltage. These devices operate on the same principle and are collectively referred to as synchronous machines.

A great simplification in the mathematical description of the synchronous machine is obtained from the Park transformation. The effect of the Park transformation is simply to transform all stator quantities from phases a, b, and c into new variables, the frame of reference of which moves with the rotor [24]. Thus by definition
The angle between the d-axis and the rotor is given by
where wR is the rated angular frequency in rad/s and δ is the synchronous torque angle in electrical radians
Similarly, to transform the voltages and flux linkages

Figure 11 shows the circuits involved in the analysis of a synchronous machine. The stator circuits consist of three-phase armature windings carrying alternating currents. The rotor circuits comprise field and amortisseur windings. The field winding is connected to a source of direct current. For the purpose of analysis, the currents in the amortisseur may be assumed to flow in two sets of closed circuits [23].

caption.p: Stator and rotor circuits of a synchronous machine

sec.p: A bond graph model of a synchronous machine on the d–q axis is shown in Fig. 12 which satisfies the following conditions: S1, the stator windings are sinusoidally distributed along the air-gap; S2, the stator slots cause no appreciable variation of the rotor inductances with rotor position; S3, magnetic hysteresis is negligible; S4, magnetic saturation effects are negligible. This bond graph is based on reference [25]; however, it has some important changes to have better machine stability.

caption.p: Bond graph of the synchronous machine with PI controller and feedback

sec.p: First, a PI controller to excitation circuit by using bonds 1 and 2 has been introduced. Then, current feedback, id, iD, and if with gains kd, kD, and kf, respectively, on the voltage input vd is applied. Finally, another current feedback to the q-circuit using the gains kq and kQ for iq and iQ, respectively, to voltage input vq is considered.

Also, in Fig. 12, Tm is the mechanical torque, Jr is the moment of inertia, I:MdDF and I:MqQ are the magnetic coupling between self- and mutual inductances of the windings on the d-axis and q-axis, respectively. rF, LF, and vF denote the resistance, self-inductance, and voltage on the field winding. rD and LD denote the resistance and self-inductance on the d-axis amortisseur circuit. Finally, rQ and LQ denote the resistance and self-inductance on the q-axis amortisseur circuit.

In this study, it is assumed that the generator is connected to a bus whose voltage and frequency remain constant, at the rated values, regardless of the stator current. This is commonly referred to as an infinite bus, because its characteristics do not change regardless of the power supplied or consumed by any device connected to it.

In order to apply a variable load connected between the synchronous generator and infinite bus, adapted bonds are proposed as shown in Fig. 13. Hence, the synchronous generator requires the transformation between electrical quantities of the armature windings of the model generator and those of the real three-phase armature windings shown in Fig. 13. Also, at the generator terminals a R and L load on each phase using adapted bonds is connected.

caption.p: Complete bond graph model of the synchronous generator with variable load

sec.p:
The parameters of the synchronous generator were obtained from the literature [24]: apparent energy 160 MVA, power factor 0.85, voltage 15 kV, current 6158 A, frequency 60 Hz, excitation current 926 A, and excitation voltage 375 V. The stator quantities, the rated power, output voltage, output current, and the angular frequency are as follows: SB = 160 MVA/3 = 53.3333 MVA,
V B
= 15 kV /
3
= 8 . 66 kV
, IB = 6158 A, wB = 2πf rad/s, IfB = 326.64 A, VfB = 163 280.68 V, and RfB = 499.89Ω. The time, flux, resistance, and inductance quantities are: tB = 1/(2π60 Hz) = 2.626 ms, λB = VBtB = 22.972V s, RB = VB/IB = 1.406Ω, LB = VB/(IB/tB) = 3.73 mH. Finally, the parameters of the synchronous machine and external network in p.u. are: Ld = 1.70, Lq = 1.64, Lf = 1.65, LD = 1.605, LQ = 1.526, Mdf = MdD = MDf = 1.55, MqQ = 1.49, rd = rq = 0.001 096, rF = 0.000 74, rD = 0.0131, rQ = 0.054, La = Lb = Lc = 0.1, Ra = Rb = Rc = 100, Vf = 0.0022, V∞ = 1.0 and Tm = 3.

It is instructive to observe the dynamic performance of a synchronous generator during a change on the load and at terminals voltage. First, the generator was operating under nominal conditions, which is shown in Fig. 14 and 15; from 0 to 1000 s, the steady state response in p.u. is: id = −1.6709, iq = 0.6469, iQ = −0.00018, iD = 0.0048, and wR = 1.067; these values from the literature [24] were verified. Also, the flux linkages are given by

where equations (30) are represented by I-fields. These fields on the bond graph of Fig. 12 are I:MdDf and I:MqQ; by substituting parameters and given currents into (30), the flux linkages are λd = 1.7748, λq = 1.0606, λD = 2.0181, λQ = 0.9638, λf = 2.3153. The electromagnetic torque is defined by
from the given currents and flux linkages, the torque is Te = 2.92. Note that mechanical torque applied to the generator is Tm = 3 to consider nominal conditions.

caption.p: Performance of the id, iq, ia, iLa and va of the system
Dynamic behaviour of the variables iD, iQ, if and wR

sec.p: The ia and va variables are the current and voltage on the phase a, and iLa is current of the load on the phase a. Also, the amortissuer currents iD and iQ, the excitation current if and the angular velocity wR are shown in Fig. 14. The dynamic profile performance of the system can be revised from the literature [24, 26].

In order to know the generator performance when the terminal voltage is reduced, a signal pulse, Gt2, from 1000 s to 1050 s is applied to the adapted bonds to reduce 20 per cent of the nominal voltage, as shown in Figs 14 and 15. Reference [27] presents a study of a synchronous machine stability under voltage sags, where a voltage sag is a short-duration drop of between 10 per cent and 90 per cent in the magnitude of the voltage. Hence, the bond graph of a synchronous generator under voltage sags is qualitatively compared with respect to reference [27] and the results are in accord with this reference.

From 1200 s to 1250 s, the initial load, Gc1 = 30 per cent, connected to the generator is changed by a signal pulse, GC2 = 60 per cent, and in this period the load is 90 per cent with respect to the nominal.

References [28, 29] describe the effectiveness of a proportional–integral–derivative (PID) control on the excitation winding; the behaviour of the system using a PI controller to a bond graph has a qualitative profile respect to these references. In order to prove the steady-state excitation current is obtained by if = Vf/rf = 0.0022/0.000 74 = 2.9729 p.u. The base current for the excitation winding is IfB = 326.64A, then the real current is if = 2.9729 * 326.64 A = 971.068 A. Figure 15 shows the excitation current performance verifying the real current.

A three-phase fault or short-circuit rarely occurs and a three-phase fault at the machine terminals is even less common; nevertheless it is instructive to observe the dynamic performance of a synchronous machine during this type of fault. By using the adapted bonds a three-phase fault at 1500 s lasting 50 s is applied. Figures 14 and 15 show that it is a critical fault and id, iq, and if have maximum magnitude. Reference [30] analyses a three-phase fault of a synchronous generator of 125 kW by using a linearized model and the id, iq, and iq performance have a similar profile as in this paper. Also, the qualitative analysis of the three-phase fault to a synchronous generator of this paper can be verified in reference [26].

Note that the amortisseur currents on the axis d and q, iD and iQ, respectively, have to dissipate the dynamic period during a three-phase fault and after this are zero. This is to be expected since, under steady state conditions, the rotating magnetic field due to the stator currents is stationary with respect to the rotor.
This approach to an electrical power system under balanced or unbalanced conditions can be applied.

sec.title: 6 Bond Graph Model of a Closed-Loop System
sec.p: A control system consists of subsystems and processes assembled for the purpose of controlling the outputs of the processes [31]. Sensor fault detection and validation are a prerequisite in applying an effective model-based control to industrial processes [20]. A general scheme based on the junction structures of the controller and the plant in a bond graph model is presented in Fig. 16. By using adapted bonds, the connection between controller and plant, and the output feedback are obtained. This scheme can be used to obtain the closed-loop system properties.

caption.p: General scheme of a closed-loop system in a bond graph

sec.p: The closed-loop realization (Acp, Bcp, Ccp, Dcp) from the junction structure of the bond graph model of Fig. 16 using the following proposition can be obtained.

p.italic: Consider the bond graph model with an integral causality assignment of the closed-loop system of Fig. 16. Let Scp be the junction structure of the bond graph model defined by

Note that the state space of the closed-loop system has an uncertainty ξ due to the adapted bonds. If ξ = 0 is set, then the closed-loop system without the loading effect is obtained.
In the next section, the transfer function of a bond graph model using adapted bonds in a closed-loop system is obtained.

sec.title: 6.1 Transfer function of the closed-loop system
sec.p: We have been working with individual systems represented by a bond graph with their inputs and outputs. More complicated systems, however, are represented by the interconnection of many subsystems. Since the response of a single transfer function can be calculated, it is desired to represent multiple subsystems as a single transfer function.
The loop rule gives the transfer function between any input and any output. The loop rule is defined by [22]
with

where Ti(s) is the forward path gain i,

is the sum of all single causal-loop gains,

is the sum of products gain of all combinations of two nontouching single causal loops,
∑

B i
B j
B k
is the sum of gain products of all combinations of three nontouching single causal loops, and Δi(s) is similar to Δ(s) but excluding terms including single loops and their combinations that touch the ith forward path [2, 22].

By using adapted bonds in a closed-loop system scheme to obtain the transfer function applying Mason’s rule, it is necessary to use the relationships between flows and efforts given in Fig. 3. A case of causal path through of adapted bonds is shown in Fig. 17.

caption.p: An example of causal path with an adapted bond

Note that care should be taken when the forward path or causal loop has an adapted bond. The next section gives an example of closed-loop system.

sec.title: 6.2 Example
sec.p: Consider a bond graph model formed by a DC motor, a proportional and integral controller, and the output feedback shown in Fig. 19. In order to analyse the behaviour of the closed-loop system under loading effects, adapted bonds to connect the controller with the plant and the feedback are used.

caption.p: Proportional and integral control of a DC motor in a bond graph

sec.p: In this system, the adapted bond 7 indicates that the velocity sensor has a possible fault. Hence, the sensor has a load effect on the mechanical subsystem. The sensor fault can be thought of as a mechanical tachometer that it has a fault due to its DC motor shaft.
The key vectors of the bond graph model of Fig. 19 are
The constitutive relations of the storage and dissipation fields are
and the junction structure is
From (35) to (38), (39) and from (49) to (51), the matrices of state variables are
The transfer function of the closed-loop system is defined by
the forward paths are
the determinant is
where
and
Therefore, from (53) to (57) the transfer function is
where a1 = JCLa; a2 = JCRa+fCLa+RJCξ6+RCLaξ7; a3 = n2C+RafC+nRC+Jξ6+Laξ7−nRCξ6ξ7+fRCξ6+RaRCξ7; a4 = n−nξ6ξ7+fξ6+Raξ7.

If the case ξ6 = ξ7 = 0 is taken, the typical transfer function is obtained. However, the state variables representation (52) and the transfer function (58) indicate the performance of the closed-loop system when the loading effects of the sensor and the plant are considered.

Considering different values of ξ6 and ξ7 and using the following numerical parameters of the system of Fig. 19, La = 0.1H; J = 0.5kg m2; C = 0.001F; f = 2N·m·s/rad; Ra = 10Ω; n = 10 and Va = 10 rad/s, the time response of the system with initial values ξ4 = ξ11 = 0 is shown in Fig. 20.

caption.p: Dynamic performance of the system

sec.p: Figure 20 shows the dynamic performance of the system. In the absence of the loading effect, the output is controlled by the desired response, ξ6 = ξ7 = 0. Next, the adapted bond connected between the controller and the plant changes its parameter by the signal pulse ξ6A. Then, the parameter from the adapted bond of the sensor feedback is changed applying a loading effect with ξ7A. Finally, load effects are considered changing the two adapted bond parameters with the signals ξ6B and ξ7B.

Notably, the loading effect of a system can be difficult to find in a particular case. Nevertheless, under fault conditions in the sensor or the connection between controller and plant, the loading effect analysis by using the bond graph model with the adapted bonds can be applied.

sec.title: 7 Conclusions
sec.p: An adapted bond to consider the loading effect of a system modelling in bond graph has been presented. The loading effect analysis of a synchronous generator in the physical domain is proposed. This approach to an electrical power system with several power generators changing the supplied power using a bond graph model with adapted bonds can be applied. In order to consider fault cases the loading effects meaning of a closed-loop system using adapted bonds to connect controller, plant and feedback can be applied. Finally, the transfer function with the loading effect of the closed-loop system using causal paths and causal loops has been obtained.

fn.p: This research received support from the University of Michoacan.
